This Java class represents a bed design element using Java Swing. Let's break down the code:

  1. Imports: The necessary Java AWT and geometric packages are imported.

  2. Bed Class: This class implements the DesignElement interface, indicating it represents a design element that can be manipulated in a design application.

  3. Properties:

    • DEFAULT_BED_WIDTH and DEFAULT_BED_HEIGHT: Constants representing the default width and height of the bed.
    • bedWidth and bedHeight: Variables representing the current width and height of the bed.
    • startPoint: Represents the starting point (coordinates) of the bed.
    • isSelected: Indicates whether the bed is selected or not.
    • rotationAngle: Represents the rotation angle of the bed.

  4. Methods:

    • getStartPoint(), setStartPoint(): Getter and setter methods for the starting point of the bed.
    • draw(Graphics2D g): Method to draw the bed on a Graphics2D object.
    • getBounds(): Method to get the bounding box of the bed.
    • isSelected(), setSelected(boolean selected): Getter and setter methods for the selection status of the bed.
    • resize(double scale): Method to resize the bed based on a given scale factor.
    • rotate(int angle): Method to rotate the bed by a specified angle.

  5. Drawing:

    • The draw() method draws the bed, including the frame, pillow, and blanket.
    • The drawing is done by translating and rotating the graphics context and then drawing the bed components accordingly.

  6. Bounding Box:

    • The getBounds() method calculates the bounding box of the bed, considering its rotation.

Overall, this class provides functionality to draw, resize, rotate, and select a bed design element within a graphical design application implemented using Java Swing.

When the draw() method of the Bed class is called, it renders a bed design on a Graphics2D object. The bed consists of a frame, a pillow, and a blanket. Here's a description of what it looks like when drawn:

  • The bed frame is drawn as a rectangle.
  • A pillow is positioned on top of the bed frame, slightly offset from the center horizontally and closer to the top vertically.
  • A blanket is drawn at the bottom of the bed, covering a portion of the bed frame.
  • The bed is drawn at the specified location (start point) and rotated by the rotation angle if specified.

It's important to note that the actual appearance of the bed when drawn depends on factors such as the color settings, stroke thickness, and any transformations applied (such as rotation). However, based on the code provided, the bed would generally appear as a rectangular bed frame with a pillow and a blanket, as described above.

now, I wants you to make a code that draws sofa
ChatGPT

Sure, here's a simple example of a Sofa class that draws a basic sofa design using Java Swing:

java
import java.awt.*;

public class Sofa implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_SOFA_WIDTH = 100;
    private static final int DEFAULT_SOFA_HEIGHT = 50;
    private int sofaWidth = DEFAULT_SOFA_WIDTH;
    private int sofaHeight = DEFAULT_SOFA_HEIGHT;
    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;

    public Sofa(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.BLUE);
        }

        // Draw sofa base
        g.fillRect(startPoint.x, startPoint.y, sofaWidth, sofaHeight);

        // Draw sofa backrest
        g.fillRect(startPoint.x, startPoint.y - sofaHeight / 2, sofaWidth, sofaHeight / 2);

        // Draw sofa arms
        g.fillRect(startPoint.x - sofaWidth / 6, startPoint.y, sofaWidth / 6, sofaHeight);
        g.fillRect(startPoint.x + sofaWidth, startPoint.y, sofaWidth / 6, sofaHeight);

        // Draw sofa legs
        g.fillRect(startPoint.x - sofaWidth / 6, startPoint.y + sofaHeight, sofaWidth / 6, sofaHeight / 4);
        g.fillRect(startPoint.x + sofaWidth - sofaWidth / 6, startPoint.y + sofaHeight, sofaWidth / 6, sofaHeight / 4);
    }

    @Override
    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        return new Rectangle(startPoint.x, startPoint.y - sofaHeight / 2, sofaWidth, sofaHeight);
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {
        sofaWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_SOFA_WIDTH);
        sofaHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_SOFA_HEIGHT);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        // Rotation not supported for this basic sofa implementation
    }
}

This Sofa class draws a simple sofa shape consisting of a base, backrest, arms, and legs. You can customize this code further to add more details or enhance its appearance as needed.

Anonymous
need to support rotate
ChatGPT

To support rotation for the Sofa class, we can modify it to rotate around a pivot point. Here's the updated Sofa class with rotation support:

java
import java.awt.*;
import java.awt.geom.AffineTransform;

public class Sofa implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_SOFA_WIDTH = 100;
    private static final int DEFAULT_SOFA_HEIGHT = 50;
    private int sofaWidth = DEFAULT_SOFA_WIDTH;
    private int sofaHeight = DEFAULT_SOFA_HEIGHT;
    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

    public Sofa(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.BLUE);
        }

        // Save the current graphics transformation
        AffineTransform oldTransform = g.getTransform();

        // Translate and rotate the graphics context to draw the sofa at the desired position and angle
        g.translate(startPoint.x, startPoint.y);
        g.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle));

        // Draw sofa base
        g.fillRect(-sofaWidth / 2, 0, sofaWidth, sofaHeight);

        // Draw sofa backrest
        g.fillRect(-sofaWidth / 2, -sofaHeight / 2, sofaWidth, sofaHeight / 2);

        // Draw sofa arms
        g.fillRect(-sofaWidth / 2 - sofaWidth / 6, 0, sofaWidth / 6, sofaHeight);
        g.fillRect(sofaWidth / 2, 0, sofaWidth / 6, sofaHeight);

        // Draw sofa legs
        g.fillRect(-sofaWidth / 2 - sofaWidth / 6, sofaHeight, sofaWidth / 6, sofaHeight / 4);
        g.fillRect(sofaWidth / 2, sofaHeight, sofaWidth / 6, sofaHeight / 4);

        // Restore the old graphics transformation
        g.setTransform(oldTransform);
    }

    @Override
    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        // Calculate the bounding box of the sofa
        AffineTransform transform = new AffineTransform();
        transform.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle), startPoint.x, startPoint.y);
        Shape rotatedShape = transform.createTransformedShape(new Rectangle(startPoint.x - sofaWidth / 2, startPoint.y - sofaHeight / 2, sofaWidth, sofaHeight));
        return rotatedShape.getBounds();
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {
        sofaWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_SOFA_WIDTH);
        sofaHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_SOFA_HEIGHT);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

In this updated version, the draw() method first saves the current graphics transformation, then translates and rotates the graphics context to draw the sofa at the desired position and angle. After drawing the sofa, it restores the original graphics transformation. Additionally, the getBounds() method is modified to calculate the bounding box of the rotated sofa.

Based on the provided Bed class, let's adjust the Sofa drawing to ensure it's appropriately sized relative to the bed and also draw the sofa as an outline, similar to the bed. Here's the modified Sofa class:

java
import java.awt.*;
import java.awt.geom.AffineTransform;

public class Sofa implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_SOFA_WIDTH = 80;
    private static final int DEFAULT_SOFA_HEIGHT = 40;
    private int sofaWidth = DEFAULT_SOFA_WIDTH;
    private int sofaHeight = DEFAULT_SOFA_HEIGHT;
    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

    public Sofa(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.BLUE);
        }

        // Save the current graphics transformation
        AffineTransform oldTransform = g.getTransform();

        // Translate and rotate the graphics context to draw the sofa at the desired position and angle
        g.translate(startPoint.x, startPoint.y);
        g.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle));

        // Draw sofa base outline
        g.drawRect(-sofaWidth / 2, 0, sofaWidth, sofaHeight);

        // Draw sofa backrest outline
        g.drawRect(-sofaWidth / 2, -sofaHeight / 2, sofaWidth, sofaHeight / 2);

        // Draw sofa arms outline
        g.drawRect(-sofaWidth / 2 - sofaWidth / 6, 0, sofaWidth / 6, sofaHeight);
        g.drawRect(sofaWidth / 2, 0, sofaWidth / 6, sofaHeight);

        // Draw sofa legs outline
        g.drawRect(-sofaWidth / 2 - sofaWidth / 6, sofaHeight, sofaWidth / 6, sofaHeight / 4);
        g.drawRect(sofaWidth / 2, sofaHeight, sofaWidth / 6, sofaHeight / 4);

        // Restore the old graphics transformation
        g.setTransform(oldTransform);
    }

    @Override
    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        // Calculate the bounding box of the sofa
        AffineTransform transform = new AffineTransform();
        transform.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle), startPoint.x, startPoint.y);
        Shape rotatedShape = transform.createTransformedShape(new Rectangle(startPoint.x - sofaWidth / 2, startPoint.y - sofaHeight / 2, sofaWidth, sofaHeight));
        return rotatedShape.getBounds();
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {
        sofaWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_SOFA_WIDTH);
        sofaHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_SOFA_HEIGHT);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

In this updated version:

  • The size of the sofa (DEFAULT_SOFA_WIDTH and DEFAULT_SOFA_HEIGHT) is adjusted to be smaller than the bed for better visual comparison.
  • The draw() method now draws the sofa as an outline using drawRect() instead of fillRect(), which produces an outline drawing similar to the bed.

This modification should provide a sofa drawing that is appropriately sized compared to the bed and presented as an outline.

I see, to make the sofa smaller in comparison to the bed, we can adjust its dimensions relative to the bed size. Let's consider making the sofa roughly half the size of the bed. Here's the adjusted Sofa class:

java
import java.awt.*;
import java.awt.geom.AffineTransform;

public class Sofa implements DesignElement {
    private static final double SOFA_SIZE_RATIO = 0.5; // Ratio of sofa size to bed size
    private int sofaWidth;
    private int sofaHeight;
    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

    public Sofa(Point startPoint, int bedWidth, int bedHeight) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
        this.sofaWidth = (int) (bedWidth * SOFA_SIZE_RATIO);
        this.sofaHeight = (int) (bedHeight * SOFA_SIZE_RATIO);
    }

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.BLUE);
        }

        // Save the current graphics transformation
        AffineTransform oldTransform = g.getTransform();

        // Translate and rotate the graphics context to draw the sofa at the desired position and angle
        g.translate(startPoint.x, startPoint.y);
        g.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle));

        // Draw sofa base outline
        g.drawRect(-sofaWidth / 2, 0, sofaWidth, sofaHeight);

        // Draw sofa backrest outline
        g.drawRect(-sofaWidth / 2, -sofaHeight / 2, sofaWidth, sofaHeight / 2);

        // Draw sofa arms outline
        g.drawRect(-sofaWidth / 2 - sofaWidth / 6, 0, sofaWidth / 6, sofaHeight);
        g.drawRect(sofaWidth / 2, 0, sofaWidth / 6, sofaHeight);

        // Draw sofa legs outline
        g.drawRect(-sofaWidth / 2 - sofaWidth / 6, sofaHeight, sofaWidth / 6, sofaHeight / 4);
        g.drawRect(sofaWidth / 2, sofaHeight, sofaWidth / 6, sofaHeight / 4);

        // Restore the old graphics transformation
        g.setTransform(oldTransform);
    }

    @Override
    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        // Calculate the bounding box of the sofa
        AffineTransform transform = new AffineTransform();
        transform.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle), startPoint.x, startPoint.y);
        Shape rotatedShape = transform.createTransformedShape(new Rectangle(startPoint.x - sofaWidth / 2, startPoint.y - sofaHeight / 2, sofaWidth, sofaHeight));
        return rotatedShape.getBounds();
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {
        // Not used for the sofa since its size is determined relative to the bed size
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

In this adjustment:

  • We introduce a SOFA_SIZE_RATIO constant, which determines the ratio of the sofa size to the bed size.
  • The constructor of Sofa now takes the dimensions of the bed (bedWidth and bedHeight) and calculates the dimensions of the sofa based on the defined ratio.
  • The rest of the Sofa class remains the same, drawing the sofa as an outline and supporting rotation.

Certainly, we can remove the constructor and calculate the sofa dimensions outside the class. Here's the adjusted Sofa class:

java
import java.awt.*;
import java.awt.geom.AffineTransform;

public class Sofa implements DesignElement {
    private static final double SOFA_SIZE_RATIO = 0.5; // Ratio of sofa size to bed size
    private int sofaWidth;
    private int sofaHeight;
    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

    public Sofa(Point startPoint, int sofaWidth, int sofaHeight) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
        this.sofaWidth = sofaWidth;
        this.sofaHeight = sofaHeight;
    }

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.BLUE);
        }

        // Save the current graphics transformation
        AffineTransform oldTransform = g.getTransform();

        // Translate and rotate the graphics context to draw the sofa at the desired position and angle
        g.translate(startPoint.x, startPoint.y);
        g.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle));

        // Draw sofa base outline
        g.drawRect(-sofaWidth / 2, 0, sofaWidth, sofaHeight);

        // Draw sofa backrest outline
        g.drawRect(-sofaWidth / 2, -sofaHeight / 2, sofaWidth, sofaHeight / 2);

        // Draw sofa arms outline
        g.drawRect(-sofaWidth / 2 - sofaWidth / 6, 0, sofaWidth / 6, sofaHeight);
        g.drawRect(sofaWidth / 2, 0, sofaWidth / 6, sofaHeight);

        // Draw sofa legs outline
        g.drawRect(-sofaWidth / 2 - sofaWidth / 6, sofaHeight, sofaWidth / 6, sofaHeight / 4);
        g.drawRect(sofaWidth / 2, sofaHeight, sofaWidth / 6, sofaHeight / 4);

        // Restore the old graphics transformation
        g.setTransform(oldTransform);
    }

    @Override
    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        // Calculate the bounding box of the sofa
        AffineTransform transform = new AffineTransform();
        transform.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle), startPoint.x, startPoint.y);
        Shape rotatedShape = transform.createTransformedShape(new Rectangle(startPoint.x - sofaWidth / 2, startPoint.y - sofaHeight / 2, sofaWidth, sofaHeight));
        return rotatedShape.getBounds();
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {
        // Not used for the sofa since its size is determined outside the class
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

Now, the constructor of Sofa only takes the startPoint, sofaWidth, and sofaHeight as arguments. The SOFA_SIZE_RATIO is no longer used as the dimensions are determined outside the class. This gives more flexibility in defining the sofa size independently of the bed size.

Sure, here's a simple implementation of a Stove class in Java, which will draw a basic stove design using Java's Graphics2D:

java
import java.awt.*;

public class Stove implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_STOVE_WIDTH = 60;
    private static final int DEFAULT_STOVE_HEIGHT = 40;
    private int stoveWidth = DEFAULT_STOVE_WIDTH;
    private int stoveHeight = DEFAULT_STOVE_HEIGHT;
    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

    public Stove(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.GRAY);
        }

        // Save the current graphics transformation
        AffineTransform oldTransform = g.getTransform();

        // Translate and rotate the graphics context to draw the stove at the desired position and angle
        g.translate(startPoint.x, startPoint.y);
        g.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle));

        // Draw stove body
        g.fillRect(-stoveWidth / 2, -stoveHeight / 2, stoveWidth, stoveHeight);

        // Draw stove burners
        int burnerSize = Math.min(stoveWidth, stoveHeight) / 4;
        int burnerX = -burnerSize / 2;
        int burnerY = -stoveHeight / 4;
        for (int i = 0; i < 4; i++) {
            g.fillOval(burnerX, burnerY, burnerSize, burnerSize);
            burnerX += stoveWidth / 3;
        }

        // Restore the old graphics transformation
        g.setTransform(oldTransform);
    }

    @Override
    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        return new Rectangle(startPoint.x - stoveWidth / 2, startPoint.y - stoveHeight / 2, stoveWidth, stoveHeight);
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {
        stoveWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_STOVE_WIDTH);
        stoveHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_STOVE_HEIGHT);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

This Stove class draws a basic stove design consisting of a rectangular body and four circular burners. You can customize this code further to add more details or enhance its appearance as needed.

java
import java.awt.*;

public class Toilet implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_TOILET_WIDTH = 40;
    private static final int DEFAULT_TOILET_HEIGHT = 60;
    private int toiletWidth = DEFAULT_TOILET_WIDTH;
    private int toiletHeight = DEFAULT_TOILET_HEIGHT;
    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

    public Toilet(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.BLACK);
        }

        // Save the current graphics transformation
        AffineTransform oldTransform = g.getTransform();

        // Translate and rotate the graphics context to draw the toilet at the desired position and angle
        g.translate(startPoint.x, startPoint.y);
        g.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle));

        // Draw toilet outline
        g.drawRect(-toiletWidth / 2, -toiletHeight / 2, toiletWidth, toiletHeight);

        // Draw toilet seat outline
        int seatWidth = toiletWidth - 10;
        int seatHeight = toiletHeight / 3;
        g.drawRect(-seatWidth / 2, -toiletHeight / 2, seatWidth, seatHeight);

        // Draw toilet tank outline
        int tankWidth = toiletWidth / 3;
        int tankHeight = toiletHeight - seatHeight;
        g.drawRect(-tankWidth / 2, -seatHeight / 2, tankWidth, tankHeight);

        // Restore the old graphics transformation
        g.setTransform(oldTransform);
    }

    @Override
    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        return new Rectangle(startPoint.x - toiletWidth / 2, startPoint.y - toiletHeight / 2, toiletWidth, toiletHeight);
    }

        return isSelected;
    }

        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override

        toiletWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_TOILET_WIDTH);
        toiletHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_TOILET_HEIGHT);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

        g.translate(startPoint.x, startPoint.y);
        g.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle));

To make the outline of the toilet thicker, you can adjust the stroke of the Graphics2D object. Here's the modified draw() method with a thicker line:

java
@Override
public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
    if (isSelected) {
        g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
    } else {
        g.setColor(Color.BLACK);
    }

    // Save the current graphics transformation
    AffineTransform oldTransform = g.getTransform();

    // Translate and rotate the graphics context to draw the toilet at the desired position and angle
    g.translate(startPoint.x, startPoint.y);
    g.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle));

    // Set the stroke to a thicker line
    g.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2.0f)); // Adjust the thickness as needed

    // Draw oblate toilet body outline
    g.drawOval(-toiletRadiusX, -toiletRadiusY, 2 * toiletRadiusX, 2 * toiletRadiusY);

    // Draw toilet tank outline
    int tankWidth = toiletRadiusX / 2;
    int tankHeight = toiletRadiusY * 2;
    g.drawRect(toiletRadiusX, -tankHeight / 2, tankWidth, tankHeight);

    // Restore the old graphics transformation
    g.setTransform(oldTransform);
}

In this modification:

  • The BasicStroke class is used to create a stroke object with the desired thickness (in this case, 2.0f).
  • This stroke object is then set using the setStroke() method of the Graphics2D object g.
  • The toilet outline and tank are then drawn with the thicker stroke.

Certainly! Below is a simple implementation of a Plant class that draws an outline of a plant:

java
import java.awt.*;

public class Plant implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_PLANT_WIDTH = 20;
    private static final int DEFAULT_PLANT_HEIGHT = 40;
    private int plantWidth = DEFAULT_PLANT_WIDTH;
    private int plantHeight = DEFAULT_PLANT_HEIGHT;
    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

    public Plant(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.GREEN);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.BLACK);
        }

        // Save the current graphics transformation
        AffineTransform oldTransform = g.getTransform();

        // Translate and rotate the graphics context to draw the plant at the desired position and angle
        g.translate(startPoint.x, startPoint.y);
        g.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle));

        // Draw plant outline
        g.drawRect(-plantWidth / 2, -plantHeight / 2, plantWidth, plantHeight);

        // Draw leaves outline
        int leafWidth = plantWidth * 3 / 4;
        int leafHeight = plantHeight / 2;
        g.drawRect(-leafWidth / 2, -plantHeight / 2 - leafHeight, leafWidth, leafHeight);
        g.drawRect(-leafWidth / 2, -plantHeight / 2 - leafHeight * 2, leafWidth, leafHeight);

        // Restore the old graphics transformation
        g.setTransform(oldTransform);
    }

    @Override
    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        return new Rectangle(startPoint.x - plantWidth / 2, startPoint.y - plantHeight / 2, plantWidth, plantHeight);
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {
        plantWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_PLANT_WIDTH);
        plantHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_PLANT_HEIGHT);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

In this implementation:

  • The plant outline is drawn using drawRect() method to create a simple rectangular shape.
  • The leaves outline are also drawn using drawRect() to create additional details.

You can further customize this implementation by adding more details or adjusting the shape as needed. If you have any further questions or need additional modifications, feel free to ask!

you know what, just draw a flower with stem
ChatGPT

Sure! Here's an implementation of a Flower class that draws a simple flower with a stem:

java
import java.awt.*;

public class Flower implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_FLOWER_WIDTH = 30;
    private static final int DEFAULT_FLOWER_HEIGHT = 40;
    private int flowerWidth = DEFAULT_FLOWER_WIDTH;
    private int flowerHeight = DEFAULT_FLOWER_HEIGHT;
    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

    public Flower(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.RED);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.YELLOW);
        }

        // Save the current graphics transformation
        AffineTransform oldTransform = g.getTransform();

        // Translate and rotate the graphics context to draw the flower at the desired position and angle
        g.translate(startPoint.x, startPoint.y);
        g.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle));

        // Draw stem
        g.drawRect(-2, 0, 4, flowerHeight);

        // Draw flower petals
        for (int i = 0; i < 8; i++) {
            g.fillOval(-flowerWidth / 2, -flowerHeight / 2, flowerWidth, flowerHeight);
            g.rotate(Math.toRadians(45));
        }

        // Restore the old graphics transformation
        g.setTransform(oldTransform);
    }

    @Override
    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        return new Rectangle(startPoint.x - flowerWidth / 2, startPoint.y - flowerHeight / 2, flowerWidth, flowerHeight);
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {
        flowerWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_FLOWER_WIDTH);
        flowerHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_FLOWER_HEIGHT);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

In this implementation:

  • The flower petals are drawn using fillOval() method to create a circular shape.
  • The stem is drawn as a simple rectangle using drawRect() method.
  • The rotation of the petals creates the flower shape.

You can adjust the number of petals, colors, or add more details as needed. If you have any further questions or need additional modifications, feel free to ask!

        g.drawRect(-leafWidth / 2, -plantHeight / 2 - leafHeight, leafWidth, leafHeight);
        g.drawRect(-leafWidth / 2, -plantHeight / 2 - leafHeight * 2, leafWidth, leafHeight);

        // Restore the old graphics transformation
        g.setTransform(oldTransform);
    }

    @Override
    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        return new Rectangle(startPoint.x - plantWidth / 2, startPoint.y - plantHeight / 2, plantWidth, plantHeight);
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {
        plantWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_PLANT_WIDTH);
        plantHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_PLANT_HEIGHT);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

Now, the class is named Plant, and it represents a simple plant with a stem and leaves. If you have any further questions or need additional modifications, feel free to ask!

java
import java.awt.*;

public class Plant implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_PLANT_WIDTH = 40;
    private static final int DEFAULT_PLANT_HEIGHT = 40;
    private int plantWidth = DEFAULT_PLANT_WIDTH;
    private int plantHeight = DEFAULT_PLANT_HEIGHT;
    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

        this.startPoint = startPoint;

        return startPoint;
    }

        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.YELLOW);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.ORANGE);
        }

        // Save the current graphics transformation
        AffineTransform oldTransform = g.getTransform();

        // Translate and rotate the graphics context to draw the sunflower at the desired position and angle
        g.translate(startPoint.x, startPoint.y);
        g.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle));

        // Draw sunflower petals
        g.fillOval(-plantWidth / 2, -plantHeight / 2, plantWidth, plantHeight);

        // Draw sunflower center
        g.setColor(Color.BLACK);
        int centerSize = plantWidth / 4;
        g.fillOval(-centerSize / 2, -centerSize / 2, centerSize, centerSize);

        // Restore the old graphics transformation
        g.setTransform(oldTransform);
    }

    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        return new Rectangle(startPoint.x - plantWidth / 2, startPoint.y - plantHeight / 2, plantWidth, plantHeight);

    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;

    public void resize(double scale) {
        plantWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_PLANT_WIDTH);
        plantHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_PLANT_HEIGHT);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

java
import java.awt.*;

public class Plant implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_PLANT_WIDTH = 40;
    private static final int DEFAULT_PLANT_HEIGHT = 40;
    private int plantWidth = DEFAULT_PLANT_WIDTH;
    private int plantHeight = DEFAULT_PLANT_HEIGHT;
    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

    public Plant(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.YELLOW);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.ORANGE);
        }

        // Save the current graphics transformation
        AffineTransform oldTransform = g.getTransform();

        // Translate and rotate the graphics context to draw the sunflower at the desired position and angle
        g.translate(startPoint.x, startPoint.y);
        g.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle));

        // Draw sunflower petals
        for (int i = 0; i < 12; i++) {
            g.fillOval(-plantWidth / 2, -plantHeight / 2, plantWidth, plantHeight);
            g.rotate(Math.toRadians(30)); // Rotate by 30 degrees for each petal
        }

        // Draw sunflower center
        g.setColor(Color.BLACK);
        int centerSize = plantWidth / 4;
        g.fillOval(-centerSize / 2, -centerSize / 2, centerSize, centerSize);

        // Restore the old graphics transformation
        g.setTransform(oldTransform);
    }

    @Override
    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        return new Rectangle(startPoint.x - plantWidth / 2, startPoint.y - plantHeight / 2, plantWidth, plantHeight);
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {
        plantWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_PLANT_WIDTH);
        plantHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_PLANT_HEIGHT);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

In this updated implementation:

  • The sunflower petals are drawn in a loop to create a more detailed appearance.
  • Each petal is drawn using fillOval() method, rotated by 30 degrees for each petal.
  • The center of the sunflower is drawn as a smaller black circle.

This should provide a more detailed representation of a sunflower. If you have any further questions or need additional modifications, feel free to ask!

import java.awt.*;

public class Plant implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_PLANT_WIDTH = 40;
    private static final int DEFAULT_PLANT_HEIGHT = 40;
    private int plantWidth = DEFAULT_PLANT_WIDTH;
    private int plantHeight = DEFAULT_PLANT_HEIGHT;

    private boolean isSelected = false;

        return startPoint;

        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.RED);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.PINK);
        }

        // Save the current graphics transformation
        AffineTransform oldTransform = g.getTransform();

        // Translate and rotate the graphics context to draw the rose at the desired position and angle
        g.translate(startPoint.x, startPoint.y);

        return isSelected;

        plantHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_PLANT_HEIGHT);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

In this implementation:

To draw a rose from a side viewpoint, we'll adjust the drawing logic to represent the rose petals and stem as seen from the side. Here's the modified Plant class for a side-view rose:

java
import java.awt.*;

public class Plant implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_STEM_WIDTH = 5;
    private static final int DEFAULT_STEM_HEIGHT = 60;
    private static final int DEFAULT_PETAL_WIDTH = 20;
    private static final int DEFAULT_PETAL_HEIGHT = 15;

    private int stemWidth = DEFAULT_STEM_WIDTH;
    private int stemHeight = DEFAULT_STEM_HEIGHT;
    private int petalWidth = DEFAULT_PETAL_WIDTH;
    private int petalHeight = DEFAULT_PETAL_HEIGHT;

    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

    public Plant(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.RED);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.PINK);
        }

        // Save the current graphics transformation
        AffineTransform oldTransform = g.getTransform();

        // Translate and rotate the graphics context to draw the rose at the desired position and angle
        g.translate(startPoint.x, startPoint.y);
        g.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle));

        // Draw rose stem
        g.fillRect(-stemWidth / 2, 0, stemWidth, stemHeight);

        // Draw rose petals
        for (int i = 0; i < 8; i++) {
            g.fillOval(-petalWidth / 2, -stemHeight + 5 + i * 7, petalWidth, petalHeight);
        }

        // Restore the old graphics transformation
        g.setTransform(oldTransform);
    }

    @Override
    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        return new Rectangle(startPoint.x - stemWidth / 2, startPoint.y - stemHeight, stemWidth, stemHeight);
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {
        stemWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_STEM_WIDTH);
        stemHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_STEM_HEIGHT);
        petalWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_PETAL_WIDTH);
        petalHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_PETAL_HEIGHT);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

In this implementation:

  • The rose stem is drawn using a rectangle.
  • The rose petals are drawn above the stem at various heights to represent their arrangement from the side view.

This should provide a basic representation of a rose from a side viewpoint. You can adjust the dimensions and appearance as needed. If you have any further questions or need additional modifications, feel free to ask!

To draw the rose as an outline, you can use the drawRect() and drawOval() methods instead of fillRect() and fillOval(). Here's the modified draw() method:

java
import java.awt.*;

public class Plant implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_STEM_WIDTH = 5;
    private static final int DEFAULT_STEM_HEIGHT = 60;
    private static final int DEFAULT_PETAL_WIDTH = 20;
    private static final int DEFAULT_PETAL_HEIGHT = 15;

    private int stemWidth = DEFAULT_STEM_WIDTH;
    private int stemHeight = DEFAULT_STEM_HEIGHT;
    private int petalWidth = DEFAULT_PETAL_WIDTH;
    private int petalHeight = DEFAULT_PETAL_HEIGHT;

    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

    public Plant(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.GREEN);
        }

        // Save the current graphics transformation
        AffineTransform oldTransform = g.getTransform();

        // Translate and rotate the graphics context to draw the rose at the desired position and angle
        g.translate(startPoint.x, startPoint.y);
        g.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle));

        // Draw rose stem outline
        g.drawRect(-stemWidth / 2, 0, stemWidth, stemHeight);

        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.RED);
        }
        // Draw rose petal outline
        g.drawOval(-petalWidth / 2, -stemHeight + 8 * 7, petalWidth, petalHeight);

        // Restore the old graphics transformation
        g.setTransform(oldTransform);
    }

    @Override
    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        return new Rectangle(startPoint.x - stemWidth / 2, startPoint.y - stemHeight, stemWidth, stemHeight);
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {
        stemWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_STEM_WIDTH);
        stemHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_STEM_HEIGHT);
        petalWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_PETAL_WIDTH);
        petalHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_PETAL_HEIGHT);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

In this modification:

  • The stem and petal outlines are drawn using drawRect() and drawOval() respectively, instead of fillRect() and fillOval().
  • This results in drawing the outlines of the stem and petals without filling them.

This should provide the desired outline appearance for the rose. If you have any further questions or need additional modifications, feel free to ask!

Sure, below is an implementation of the Plant class representing a cactus in a pot:

java
import java.awt.*;

public class Plant implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_POT_WIDTH = 30;
    private static final int DEFAULT_POT_HEIGHT = 20;
    private static final int DEFAULT_CACTUS_WIDTH = 10;
    private static final int DEFAULT_CACTUS_HEIGHT = 30;

    private int potWidth = DEFAULT_POT_WIDTH;
    private int potHeight = DEFAULT_POT_HEIGHT;
    private int cactusWidth = DEFAULT_CACTUS_WIDTH;
    private int cactusHeight = DEFAULT_CACTUS_HEIGHT;

    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

    public Plant(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        // Draw pot outline
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.GRAY);
        }
        g.drawRect(startPoint.x - potWidth / 2, startPoint.y - potHeight, potWidth, potHeight);

        // Draw cactus
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.GREEN);
        }
        g.fillRect(startPoint.x - cactusWidth / 2, startPoint.y - potHeight - cactusHeight, cactusWidth, cactusHeight);
    }

    @Override
    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        return new Rectangle(startPoint.x - potWidth / 2, startPoint.y - potHeight - cactusHeight, potWidth, potHeight + cactusHeight);
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {
        potWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_POT_WIDTH);
        potHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_POT_HEIGHT);
        cactusWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_CACTUS_WIDTH);
        cactusHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_CACTUS_HEIGHT);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

In this implementation:

  • The pot is drawn as a rectangle outline.
  • The cactus is drawn as a filled rectangle above the pot.

You can adjust the dimensions and appearance of the pot and cactus as needed. If you have any further questions or need additional modifications, feel free to ask!

okay, just draw a flower with 5 petal
ChatGPT

Below is an implementation of the Plant class representing a simple flower with 5 petals:

java
import java.awt.*;

public class Plant implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_FLOWER_WIDTH = 40;
    private static final int DEFAULT_FLOWER_HEIGHT = 40;

    private int flowerWidth = DEFAULT_FLOWER_WIDTH;
    private int flowerHeight = DEFAULT_FLOWER_HEIGHT;

    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

    public Plant(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.PINK);
        }

        // Draw petals
        int petalRadius = Math.min(flowerWidth, flowerHeight) / 2;
        double angleIncrement = 2 * Math.PI / 5;
        double angle = 0;
        int[] xPoints = new int[5];
        int[] yPoints = new int[5];
        for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) {
            xPoints[i] = (int) (startPoint.x + petalRadius * Math.cos(angle));
            yPoints[i] = (int) (startPoint.y + petalRadius * Math.sin(angle));
            angle += angleIncrement;
        }
        g.fillPolygon(xPoints, yPoints, 5);

        // Draw flower center
        g.setColor(Color.YELLOW);
        int centerSize = Math.min(flowerWidth, flowerHeight) / 4;
        g.fillOval(startPoint.x - centerSize / 2, startPoint.y - centerSize / 2, centerSize, centerSize);
    }

    @Override
    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        return new Rectangle(startPoint.x - flowerWidth / 2, startPoint.y - flowerHeight / 2, flowerWidth, flowerHeight);
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {
        flowerWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_FLOWER_WIDTH);
        flowerHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_FLOWER_HEIGHT);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

In this implementation:

  • The flower consists of 5 petals drawn using a polygon.
  • The flower center is drawn as a yellow circle.

You can adjust the size and appearance of the flower as needed. If you have any further questions or need additional modifications, feel free to ask!

To make the petals look like oblate circles, we can modify the way we draw the petals to create a more elongated shape. Here's the updated implementation:

java
import java.awt.*;

public class Plant implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_FLOWER_WIDTH = 40;
    private static final int DEFAULT_FLOWER_HEIGHT = 40;

    private int flowerWidth = DEFAULT_FLOWER_WIDTH;
    private int flowerHeight = DEFAULT_FLOWER_HEIGHT;

    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

    public Plant(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.PINK);
        }

        // Draw petals
        int petalRadiusX = flowerWidth / 2;
        int petalRadiusY = flowerHeight / 4;
        double angleIncrement = 2 * Math.PI / 5;
        double angle = 0;
        int[] xPoints = new int[5];
        int[] yPoints = new int[5];
        for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) {
            xPoints[i] = (int) (startPoint.x + petalRadiusX * Math.cos(angle));
            yPoints[i] = (int) (startPoint.y + petalRadiusY * Math.sin(angle));
            angle += angleIncrement;
        }
        g.fillPolygon(xPoints, yPoints, 5);

        // Draw flower center
        g.setColor(Color.YELLOW);
        int centerSize = Math.min(flowerWidth, flowerHeight) / 4;
        g.fillOval(startPoint.x - centerSize / 2, startPoint.y - centerSize / 2, centerSize, centerSize);
    }

    @Override
    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        return new Rectangle(startPoint.x - flowerWidth / 2, startPoint.y - flowerHeight / 2, flowerWidth, flowerHeight);
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {
        flowerWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_FLOWER_WIDTH);
        flowerHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_FLOWER_HEIGHT);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

In this implementation:

  • We use different radiuses for the X and Y axes to create an oblate shape.
  • The petal radius along the Y axis is set to be smaller than the radius along the X axis.
  • The rest of the code remains the same.

This should create a flower with petals resembling oblate circles. You can adjust the size and appearance of the flower as needed. If you have any further questions or need additional modifications, feel free to ask!

Apologies for the oversight. Let's reintegrate the rotation functionality into the draw() method. Here's the updated implementation:

java
import java.awt.*;

public class Plant implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_FLOWER_WIDTH = 40;
    private static final int DEFAULT_FLOWER_HEIGHT = 40;

    private int flowerWidth = DEFAULT_FLOWER_WIDTH;
    private int flowerHeight = DEFAULT_FLOWER_HEIGHT;

    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

    public Plant(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.PINK);
        }

        // Save the current graphics transformation
        AffineTransform oldTransform = g.getTransform();

        // Translate and rotate the graphics context to draw the flower at the desired position and angle
        g.translate(startPoint.x, startPoint.y);
        g.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle));

        // Draw petals
        int petalRadius = Math.min(flowerWidth, flowerHeight) / 2;
        double angleIncrement = 2 * Math.PI / 5;
        double angle = 0;
        int[] xPoints = new int[5];
        int[] yPoints = new int[5];
        for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) {
            xPoints[i] = (int) (petalRadius * Math.cos(angle));
            yPoints[i] = (int) (petalRadius * Math.sin(angle));
            angle += angleIncrement;
        }
        g.fillPolygon(xPoints, yPoints, 5);

        // Draw flower center
        g.setColor(Color.YELLOW);
        int centerSize = Math.min(flowerWidth, flowerHeight) / 4;
        g.fillOval(-centerSize / 2, -centerSize / 2, centerSize, centerSize);

        // Restore the old graphics transformation
        g.setTransform(oldTransform);
    }

    @Override
    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        return new Rectangle(startPoint.x - flowerWidth / 2, startPoint.y - flowerHeight / 2, flowerWidth, flowerHeight);
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {
        flowerWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_FLOWER_WIDTH);
        flowerHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_FLOWER_HEIGHT);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

In this implementation:

  • The draw() method now includes the rotation logic. We save the current graphics transformation, then translate and rotate the graphics context to draw the flower at the desired position and angle. After drawing the flower, we restore the old graphics transformation.

Now, the rotate() method will properly rotate the flower when called. If you have any further questions or need additional modifications, feel free to ask!

To create a top-down view outline of a chair, we'll draw the basic shape of a chair with straight lines to represent the legs, backrest, and seat. Below is an implementation of the DesignElement interface for drawing a simple chair outline:

java
import java.awt.*;

public class Chair implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_CHAIR_WIDTH = 50;
    private static final int DEFAULT_CHAIR_HEIGHT = 50;

    private int chairWidth = DEFAULT_CHAIR_WIDTH;
    private int chairHeight = DEFAULT_CHAIR_HEIGHT;

    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

    public Chair(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.GRAY);
        }

        // Draw chair legs
        int legWidth = chairWidth / 6;
        int legHeight = chairHeight / 2;
        int legOffsetX = chairWidth / 3;
        int legOffsetY = chairHeight / 4;
        g.drawRect(startPoint.x, startPoint.y, legWidth, legHeight);
        g.drawRect(startPoint.x + chairWidth - legWidth, startPoint.y, legWidth, legHeight);
        g.drawRect(startPoint.x, startPoint.y + chairHeight - legHeight, legWidth, legHeight);
        g.drawRect(startPoint.x + chairWidth - legWidth, startPoint.y + chairHeight - legHeight, legWidth, legHeight);

        // Draw chair backrest
        int backrestWidth = chairWidth - 2 * legWidth;
        int backrestHeight = chairHeight / 4;
        g.drawRect(startPoint.x + legOffsetX, startPoint.y - backrestHeight, backrestWidth, backrestHeight);

        // Draw chair seat
        int seatWidth = chairWidth - 2 * legWidth;
        int seatHeight = chairHeight / 4;
        g.drawRect(startPoint.x + legOffsetX, startPoint.y + legOffsetY, seatWidth, seatHeight);
    }

    @Override
    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        return new Rectangle(startPoint.x, startPoint.y, chairWidth, chairHeight);
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {
        chairWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_CHAIR_WIDTH);
        chairHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_CHAIR_HEIGHT);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

This implementation draws a basic chair outline with legs, backrest, and seat. You can adjust the dimensions and appearance of the chair as needed. If you have any further questions or need additional modifications, feel free to ask!

java
import java.awt.*;

public class Chair implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_CHAIR_WIDTH = 50;
    private static final int DEFAULT_CHAIR_HEIGHT = 50;

    private int chairHeight = DEFAULT_CHAIR_HEIGHT;

        this.startPoint = startPoint;

        this.startPoint = startPoint;

        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.GRAY);
        }

        // Draw chair backrest
        int backrestWidth = chairWidth / 5;
        int backrestHeight = chairHeight / 2;
        g.drawRect(startPoint.x + chairWidth / 4, startPoint.y, backrestWidth, backrestHeight);

        // Draw chair seat

        int seatHeight = chairHeight / 5;
        g.drawRect(startPoint.x + chairWidth / 8, startPoint.y + backrestHeight, seatWidth, seatHeight);

        int armrestHeight = chairHeight / 10;
        g.drawRect(startPoint.x + chairWidth / 8, startPoint.y + backrestHeight / 2, armrestWidth, armrestHeight);
        g.drawRect(startPoint.x + chairWidth / 8, startPoint.y + backrestHeight / 2 + armrestHeight, legWidth, legHeight);

    }

        return new Rectangle(startPoint.x, startPoint.y, chairWidth, chairHeight);

        return isSelected;
    }

        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {

        chairHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_CHAIR_HEIGHT);

To draw a simple desk outline, we can create a rectangular shape with four legs. Here's an implementation:

java
import java.awt.*;

public class Desk implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_DESK_WIDTH = 100;
    private static final int DEFAULT_DESK_HEIGHT = 60;
    private static final int DEFAULT_LEG_WIDTH = 5;

    private int deskWidth = DEFAULT_DESK_WIDTH;
    private int deskHeight = DEFAULT_DESK_HEIGHT;
    private int legWidth = DEFAULT_LEG_WIDTH;

    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

    public Desk(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.DARK_GRAY);
        }

        // Draw desk top
        g.drawRect(startPoint.x, startPoint.y, deskWidth, deskHeight);

        // Draw desk legs
        int legHeight = deskHeight / 2;
        int legOffsetX = legWidth / 2;
        g.drawRect(startPoint.x - legOffsetX, startPoint.y - legOffsetX, legWidth, legHeight);
        g.drawRect(startPoint.x + deskWidth - legOffsetX, startPoint.y - legOffsetX, legWidth, legHeight);
        g.drawRect(startPoint.x - legOffsetX, startPoint.y + deskHeight - legHeight - legOffsetX, legWidth, legHeight);
        g.drawRect(startPoint.x + deskWidth - legOffsetX, startPoint.y + deskHeight - legHeight - legOffsetX, legWidth, legHeight);
    }

    @Override
    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        return new Rectangle(startPoint.x, startPoint.y, deskWidth, deskHeight);
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {
        deskWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_DESK_WIDTH);
        deskHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_DESK_HEIGHT);
        legWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_LEG_WIDTH);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

This Desk class draws a simple desk with a rectangular top and four legs. You can adjust the dimensions and appearance as needed. If you have any further questions or need additional modifications, feel free to ask!

java
@Override
public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
    if (isSelected) {
        g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
    } else {
        g.setColor(Color.DARK_GRAY);
    }
    g.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2));

    // Save the current graphics transformation
    AffineTransform oldTransform = g.getTransform();

    // Translate and rotate the graphics context to draw the desk at the desired position and angle
    g.translate(startPoint.x, startPoint.y);

    g.drawRect(deskWidth - legWidth * 2, deskHeight - legWidth * 2, cornerSize, cornerSize);

    // Restore the old graphics transformation
    g.setTransform(oldTransform);

To rotate the desk around its center rather than the top-left corner, we need to adjust the translation origin before rotating. Here's the modified draw() method to achieve this:

java
@Override
public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
    if (isSelected) {
        g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
    } else {
        g.setColor(Color.DARK_GRAY);
    }
    g.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2));

    // Save the current graphics transformation
    AffineTransform oldTransform = g.getTransform();

    // Calculate the center point of the desk
    int centerX = startPoint.x + deskWidth / 2;
    int centerY = startPoint.y + deskHeight / 2;

    // Translate to the center point
    g.translate(centerX, centerY);

    // Rotate the graphics context
    g.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle));

    // Translate back to the original position
    g.translate(-centerX, -centerY);

    // Draw desk top
    g.drawRect(startPoint.x, startPoint.y, deskWidth, deskHeight);

    // Draw desk corners
    int cornerSize = legWidth * 2;
    g.drawRect(startPoint.x, startPoint.y, cornerSize, cornerSize);
    g.drawRect(startPoint.x + deskWidth - legWidth * 2, startPoint.y, cornerSize, cornerSize);
    g.drawRect(startPoint.x, startPoint.y + deskHeight - legWidth * 2, cornerSize, cornerSize);
    g.drawRect(startPoint.x + deskWidth - legWidth * 2, startPoint.y + deskHeight - legWidth * 2, cornerSize, cornerSize);

    // Restore the old graphics transformation
    g.setTransform(oldTransform);
}

In this modification, we calculate the center point of the desk and translate the graphics context to that point before rotating. After drawing the desk, we restore the original transformation. This ensures that the desk rotates around its center. If you have any further questions or need additional modifications, feel free to ask!

To rotate the chair off-center, we need to calculate the center point of the chair and then apply translation and rotation transformations. Here's how you can modify the draw() method to achieve this:

java
@Override
public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
    if (isSelected) {
        g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
    } else {
        g.setColor(Color.GRAY);
    }
    g.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2));

    // Calculate center point of the chair
    int centerX = startPoint.x + chairWidth / 2;
    int centerY = startPoint.y + chairHeight / 2;

    // Save the current graphics transformation
    AffineTransform oldTransform = g.getTransform();

    // Translate to the center point
    g.translate(centerX, centerY);

    // Rotate the graphics context
    g.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle));

    // Translate back to the original position
    g.translate(-centerX, -centerY);

    // Draw chair backrest
    int backrestWidth = chairWidth;
    int backrestHeight = chairHeight / 3;
    g.drawRect(startPoint.x, startPoint.y, backrestWidth, backrestHeight);

    // Draw chair seat
    int seatWidth = chairWidth;
    int seatHeight = chairHeight / 5;
    g.drawRect(startPoint.x, startPoint.y + backrestHeight, seatWidth, seatHeight);

    g.drawRect(startPoint.x + chairWidth - legWidth, startPoint.y + backrestHeight + seatHeight, legWidth, legHeight);

    // Restore the old graphics transformation
    g.setTransform(oldTransform);
}

This modification calculates the center point of the chair, translates the graphics context to that point, performs the rotation, and then translates back to the original position. This ensures that the chair rotates off-center based on the specified rotation angle. If you have any further questions or need additional modifications, feel free to ask!

To create a class called Desk that represents a round table similar to the existing Table class, you can follow a similar structure. Here's a basic implementation:

java
package floorplan;

import java.awt.*;
import javax.swing.*;

/**
 * Represents a round table desk element.
 */
public class Desk extends JPanel {
    private Color color;
    private int diameter;

    /**
     * Constructs a round table desk with the specified diameter and color.
     * 
     * @param diameter The diameter of the round table desk.
     * @param color The color of the round table desk.
     */
    public Desk(int diameter, Color color) {
        this.diameter = diameter;
        this.color = color;
        setPreferredSize(new Dimension(diameter, diameter));
    }

    /**
     * Sets the color of the round table desk.
     * 
     * @param color The color to set.
     */
    public void setColor(Color color) {
        this.color = color;
        repaint();
    }

    @Override
    protected void paintComponent(Graphics g) {
        super.paintComponent(g);
        Graphics2D g2d = (Graphics2D) g.create();

        // Set the color
        g2d.setColor(color);

        // Draw the round table desk
        g2d.fillOval(0, 0, diameter, diameter);

        g2d.dispose();
    }
}

You can then use this Desk class in your application similarly to how you use the Table class. For example, you can add it to your UI in the initUI() method of your App class:

java
// Create and add the desk to the west
Desk desk = new Desk(200, Color.LIGHT_GRAY);
add(desk, BorderLayout.WEST);

This code assumes that the Desk class is in the same package as your App class. Adjust the package declaration and import statements accordingly if it's in a different package. Additionally, feel free to customize the Desk class further to suit your specific requirements.

To create a round desk instead of a square desk, we need to modify the calculation of the desk's corners and rotation. Here's how you can do it:

java
// Calculate the center of the desk
int centerX = startPoint.x;
int centerY = startPoint.y;

// Calculate the radius of the round desk
int radius = Math.min(deskWidth, deskHeight) / 2;

// Calculate the coordinates of the corners of the unrotated rectangle
double angleIncrement = 2 * Math.PI / 360; // Increment angle for each point
int[] xPoints = new int[360];
int[] yPoints = new int[360];
for (int i = 0; i < 360; i++) {
    double angle = i * angleIncrement;
    xPoints[i] = (int) (centerX + radius * Math.cos(angle));
    yPoints[i] = (int) (centerY + radius * Math.sin(angle));
}

// Apply rotation to each corner
double cosTheta = Math.cos(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle));
double sinTheta = Math.sin(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle));
for (int i = 0; i < 360; i++) {
    int x = xPoints[i] - centerX;
    int y = yPoints[i] - centerY;
    xPoints[i] = (int) (x * cosTheta - y * sinTheta) + centerX;
    yPoints[i] = (int) (x * sinTheta + y * cosTheta) + centerY;
}

// Create a polygon from the rotated corners
Polygon polygon = new Polygon(xPoints, yPoints, 360);

This code calculates the coordinates of 360 points on the circumference of the circle representing the round desk. Then, it applies the rotation transformation to each point, creating a rotated polygon representing the desk. Finally, it creates a Polygon object from these rotated points.

You can use this Polygon object to draw or represent the round desk in your application. Adjust the radius, angle increment, and other parameters as needed to fit your specific requirements.

Sure, here's how you can draw a round circle desk:

java
import java.awt.*;
import javax.swing.*;

public class RoundDesk extends JPanel {
    private Color color;
    private int diameter;

    public RoundDesk(int diameter, Color color) {
        this.diameter = diameter;
        this.color = color;
        setPreferredSize(new Dimension(diameter, diameter));
    }

    public void setColor(Color color) {
        this.color = color;
        repaint();
    }

    @Override
    protected void paintComponent(Graphics g) {
        super.paintComponent(g);
        Graphics2D g2d = (Graphics2D) g.create();

        // Set color
        g2d.setColor(color);

        // Draw circle desk
        g2d.drawOval(0, 0, diameter, diameter);

        g2d.dispose();
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        JFrame frame = new JFrame("Round Desk");
        RoundDesk roundDesk = new RoundDesk(200, Color.DARK_GRAY);
        frame.getContentPane().add(roundDesk);
        frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
        frame.pack();
        frame.setLocationRelativeTo(null);
        frame.setVisible(true);
    }
}

This RoundDesk class creates a JPanel that draws a round desk with the specified diameter and color. You can adjust the diameter and color according to your preferences. The main method creates a JFrame and adds an instance of RoundDesk to it for visualization.

To draw a round table instead of a square one in the Table class, you can modify the draw method to draw a circle instead of a rectangle. Here's the updated code:

java
import java.awt.*;
import java.awt.geom.AffineTransform;
import javax.swing.*;

public class Table implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_TABLE_WIDTH = 100;
    private static final int DEFAULT_TABLE_HEIGHT = 60;
    private static final int DEFAULT_LEG_WIDTH = 5;

    private int deskWidth = DEFAULT_TABLE_WIDTH;
    private int deskHeight = DEFAULT_TABLE_HEIGHT;
    private int legWidth = DEFAULT_LEG_WIDTH;

    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.DARK_GRAY);
        }
        g.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2));

        // Save the current graphics transformation
        AffineTransform oldTransform = g.getTransform();

        // Calculate the center point of the desk
        int centerX = startPoint.x + deskWidth / 2;
        int centerY = startPoint.y + deskHeight / 2;

        // Translate to the center point
        g.translate(centerX, centerY);

        // Rotate the graphics context
        g.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle));

        // Translate back to the original position
        g.translate(-centerX, -centerY);

        // Draw desk top (circle)
        int diameter = Math.min(deskWidth, deskHeight);
        g.drawOval(startPoint.x, startPoint.y, diameter, diameter);

        // Restore the old graphics transformation
        g.setTransform(oldTransform);
    }

    @Override
    public Shape getBounds() {
        // Calculate the center of the desk
        int centerX = startPoint.x + deskWidth / 2;
        int centerY = startPoint.y + deskHeight / 2;

        // Calculate the radius of the circle
        int radius = Math.min(deskWidth, deskHeight) / 2;

        // Create a circle shape
        return new java.awt.geom.Ellipse2D.Double(centerX - radius, centerY - radius, 2 * radius, 2 * radius);
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {
        deskWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_TABLE_WIDTH);
        deskHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_TABLE_HEIGHT);
        legWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_LEG_WIDTH);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

In this modification, the draw method draws a circle instead of a rectangle for the table top. The getBounds method is updated to return a circular shape. Now, the Table class represents a round table.

To add legs to the round table, you can draw them at the four cardinal points (north, south, east, and west) of the circle. Here's the updated draw method:

java
@Override
public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
    if (isSelected) {
        g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
    } else {
        g.setColor(Color.DARK_GRAY);
    }
    g.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2));

    // Save the current graphics transformation
    AffineTransform oldTransform = g.getTransform();

    // Calculate the center point of the desk
    int centerX = startPoint.x + deskWidth / 2;
    int centerY = startPoint.y + deskHeight / 2;

    // Translate to the center point
    g.translate(centerX, centerY);

    // Rotate the graphics context
    g.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle));

    // Translate back to the original position
    g.translate(-centerX, -centerY);

    // Draw desk top (circle)
    int diameter = Math.min(deskWidth, deskHeight);
    g.drawOval(startPoint.x, startPoint.y, diameter, diameter);

    // Draw desk legs (four cardinal points)
    int legSize = legWidth * 2;
    g.drawRect(startPoint.x + deskWidth / 2 - legWidth, startPoint.y, legSize, legSize); // North leg
    g.drawRect(startPoint.x + deskWidth / 2 - legWidth, startPoint.y + deskHeight - legSize, legSize, legSize); // South leg
    g.drawRect(startPoint.x, startPoint.y + deskHeight / 2 - legWidth, legSize, legSize); // West leg
    g.drawRect(startPoint.x + deskWidth - legSize, startPoint.y + deskHeight / 2 - legWidth, legSize, legSize); // East leg

    // Restore the old graphics transformation
    g.setTransform(oldTransform);
}

This code draws four legs at the top, bottom, left, and right of the circle, respectively. Each leg is drawn as a square at a certain distance from the center of the circle, calculated based on the table width and height. Adjust the legSize variable as needed to change the size of the legs.

To create a sink, we can design a simple rectangular shape with a faucet on top. Here's a basic implementation of a sink class:

java
import java.awt.*;

public class Sink implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_SINK_WIDTH = 60;
    private static final int DEFAULT_SINK_HEIGHT = 40;
    private static final int DEFAULT_FAUCET_SIZE = 10;

    private int sinkWidth = DEFAULT_SINK_WIDTH;
    private int sinkHeight = DEFAULT_SINK_HEIGHT;
    private int faucetSize = DEFAULT_FAUCET_SIZE;

    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.LIGHT_GRAY);
        }
        g.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2));

        // Save the current graphics transformation
        AffineTransform oldTransform = g.getTransform();

        // Translate to the starting point
        g.translate(startPoint.x, startPoint.y);

        // Rotate the graphics context
        g.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle));

        // Draw sink
        g.drawRect(0, 0, sinkWidth, sinkHeight);

        // Draw faucet
        g.drawRect(sinkWidth / 2 - faucetSize / 2, -faucetSize, faucetSize, faucetSize);

        // Restore the old graphics transformation
        g.setTransform(oldTransform);
    }

    @Override
    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        return new Rectangle(startPoint.x, startPoint.y, sinkWidth, sinkHeight);
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {
        sinkWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_SINK_WIDTH);
        sinkHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_SINK_HEIGHT);
        faucetSize = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_FAUCET_SIZE);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

This Sink class draws a rectangular sink with a faucet on top. You can adjust the size and position of the sink and faucet as needed.
