To draw a lamp, we can create a class Lamp implementing the DesignElement interface. Here's a simple outline drawing of a lamp:

java
import java.awt.*;
import java.awt.geom.AffineTransform;

public class Lamp implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_BASE_WIDTH = 20;
    private static final int DEFAULT_BASE_HEIGHT = 40;
    private static final int DEFAULT_STAND_LENGTH = 60;
    private static final int DEFAULT_LAMP_WIDTH = 40;
    private static final int DEFAULT_LAMP_HEIGHT = 20;

    private int baseWidth = DEFAULT_BASE_WIDTH;
    private int baseHeight = DEFAULT_BASE_HEIGHT;
    private int standLength = DEFAULT_STAND_LENGTH;
    private int lampWidth = DEFAULT_LAMP_WIDTH;
    private int lampHeight = DEFAULT_LAMP_HEIGHT;

    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.BLACK);
        }
        g.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2));

        // Save the current graphics transformation
        AffineTransform oldTransform = g.getTransform();

        // Translate and rotate the graphics context to draw the lamp at the desired position and angle
        g.translate(startPoint.x, startPoint.y);
        g.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle));

        // Draw lamp base
        g.drawRect(-baseWidth / 2, 0, baseWidth, baseHeight);

        // Draw lamp stand
        g.drawLine(0, baseHeight, 0, baseHeight + standLength);

        // Draw lamp shade
        g.drawArc(-lampWidth / 2, baseHeight + standLength - lampHeight, lampWidth, lampHeight * 2, 0, 180);

        // Restore the old graphics transformation
        g.setTransform(oldTransform);
    }

    @Override
    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        return new Rectangle(startPoint.x - baseWidth / 2, startPoint.y, baseWidth, baseHeight + standLength + lampHeight);
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {
        baseWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_BASE_WIDTH);
        baseHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_BASE_HEIGHT);
        standLength = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_STAND_LENGTH);
        lampWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_LAMP_WIDTH);
        lampHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_LAMP_HEIGHT);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

This code will draw a simple lamp with a base, stand, and a lampshade. Adjust the dimensions and styling as needed for your specific requirements.

To draw a chimney, let's create a class Chimney implementing the DesignElement interface. Below is a basic outline drawing of a chimney:

import java.awt.*;
import java.awt.geom.AffineTransform;

public class Chimney implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_CHIMNEY_WIDTH = 20;
    private static final int DEFAULT_CHIMNEY_HEIGHT = 40;

    private int chimneyWidth = DEFAULT_CHIMNEY_WIDTH;
    private int chimneyHeight = DEFAULT_CHIMNEY_HEIGHT;

    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.GRAY);
        }
        g.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2));

        // Save the current graphics transformation
        AffineTransform oldTransform = g.getTransform();

        // Translate and rotate the graphics context to draw the chimney at the desired position and angle
        g.translate(startPoint.x, startPoint.y);
        g.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle));

        // Draw chimney body
        g.drawRect(-chimneyWidth / 2, -chimneyHeight, chimneyWidth, chimneyHeight);

        // Draw chimney top
        int topWidth = chimneyWidth * 3 / 4;
        g.drawRect(-topWidth / 2, -chimneyHeight - topWidth / 2, topWidth, topWidth / 2);

        // Restore the old graphics transformation
        g.setTransform(oldTransform);

        return new Rectangle(startPoint.x - chimneyWidth / 2, startPoint.y - chimneyHeight, chimneyWidth, chimneyHeight);

        return isSelected;

    @Override

        chimneyWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_CHIMNEY_WIDTH);
        chimneyHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_CHIMNEY_HEIGHT);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

Fireplace Flue Tiles
ChatGPT

To draw fireplace flue tiles, we can modify the chimney drawing to include the tiles. Each tile can be represented as a rectangular shape within the chimney. Here's how you can modify the Chimney class to include flue tiles:

java
import java.awt.*;
import java.awt.geom.AffineTransform;

public class Chimney implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_CHIMNEY_WIDTH = 20;
    private static final int DEFAULT_CHIMNEY_HEIGHT = 40;
    private static final int DEFAULT_TILE_WIDTH = 10;
    private static final int DEFAULT_TILE_HEIGHT = 5;
    private static final int TILE_GAP = 2; // Gap between tiles

    private int chimneyWidth = DEFAULT_CHIMNEY_WIDTH;
    private int chimneyHeight = DEFAULT_CHIMNEY_HEIGHT;
    private int tileWidth = DEFAULT_TILE_WIDTH;
    private int tileHeight = DEFAULT_TILE_HEIGHT;

    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.GRAY);
        }
        g.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2));

        // Save the current graphics transformation
        AffineTransform oldTransform = g.getTransform();

        // Translate and rotate the graphics context to draw the chimney at the desired position and angle
        g.translate(startPoint.x, startPoint.y);
        g.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle));

        // Draw chimney body
        g.drawRect(-chimneyWidth / 2, -chimneyHeight, chimneyWidth, chimneyHeight);

        // Draw chimney flue tiles
        int numTiles = chimneyWidth / (tileWidth + TILE_GAP);
        int tileY = -chimneyHeight;
        for (int i = 0; i < numTiles; i++) {
            int tileX = -chimneyWidth / 2 + i * (tileWidth + TILE_GAP);
            g.drawRect(tileX, tileY, tileWidth, tileHeight);
        }

        // Restore the old graphics transformation
        g.setTransform(oldTransform);
    }

    @Override
    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        return new Rectangle(startPoint.x - chimneyWidth / 2, startPoint.y - chimneyHeight, chimneyWidth, chimneyHeight);
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {
        chimneyWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_CHIMNEY_WIDTH);
        chimneyHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_CHIMNEY_HEIGHT);
        tileWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_TILE_WIDTH);
        tileHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_TILE_HEIGHT);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

This code will draw a chimney with flue tiles represented as rectangular shapes within the chimney body. You can adjust the dimensions and styling of the tiles as needed.

To create a mansion variant of the chimney with a more elaborate design, we can add additional details such as decorative patterns or ornaments. Here's an updated version of the Chimney class with a mansion-style design:

java
import java.awt.*;
import java.awt.geom.AffineTransform;

public class Chimney implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_CHIMNEY_WIDTH = 20;
    private static final int DEFAULT_CHIMNEY_HEIGHT = 40;
    private static final int DEFAULT_TILE_WIDTH = 10;
    private static final int DEFAULT_TILE_HEIGHT = 5;
    private static final int TILE_GAP = 2; // Gap between tiles

    private int chimneyWidth = DEFAULT_CHIMNEY_WIDTH;
    private int chimneyHeight = DEFAULT_CHIMNEY_HEIGHT;
    private int tileWidth = DEFAULT_TILE_WIDTH;
    private int tileHeight = DEFAULT_TILE_HEIGHT;

    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.GRAY);
        }
        g.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2));

        // Save the current graphics transformation
        AffineTransform oldTransform = g.getTransform();

        // Translate and rotate the graphics context to draw the chimney at the desired position and angle
        g.translate(startPoint.x, startPoint.y);
        g.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle));

        // Draw chimney body with decorative pattern
        drawDecorativePattern(g);

        // Draw chimney flue tiles
        int numTiles = chimneyWidth / (tileWidth + TILE_GAP);
        int tileY = -chimneyHeight;
        for (int i = 0; i < numTiles; i++) {
            int tileX = -chimneyWidth / 2 + i * (tileWidth + TILE_GAP);
            g.drawRect(tileX, tileY, tileWidth, tileHeight);
        }

        // Restore the old graphics transformation
        g.setTransform(oldTransform);
    }

    private void drawDecorativePattern(Graphics2D g) {
        // Example of a mansion-style decorative pattern
        g.drawRect(-chimneyWidth / 2, -chimneyHeight, chimneyWidth, chimneyHeight);
        g.drawLine(-chimneyWidth / 2, -chimneyHeight / 2, chimneyWidth / 2, -chimneyHeight / 2);
        g.drawLine(-chimneyWidth / 2, -chimneyHeight / 4, chimneyWidth / 2, -chimneyHeight / 4);
        g.drawLine(-chimneyWidth / 2, 0, chimneyWidth / 2, 0);
    }

    @Override
    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        return new Rectangle(startPoint.x - chimneyWidth / 2, startPoint.y - chimneyHeight, chimneyWidth, chimneyHeight);
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {
        chimneyWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_CHIMNEY_WIDTH);
        chimneyHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_CHIMNEY_HEIGHT);
        tileWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_TILE_WIDTH);
        tileHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_TILE_HEIGHT);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

In this version, I've added a simple mansion-style decorative pattern to the chimney body. You can further customize this pattern or add more details to match your specific mansion design.

need a detailed drawing of Masonry chimneys

Creating a detailed drawing of a masonry chimney involves intricate brickwork and mortar joints. Here's a more detailed version of the Chimney class with masonry-style design:

java
import java.awt.*;
import java.awt.geom.AffineTransform;

public class MasonryChimney implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_CHIMNEY_WIDTH = 20;
    private static final int DEFAULT_CHIMNEY_HEIGHT = 40;
    private static final int DEFAULT_BRICK_WIDTH = 5;
    private static final int DEFAULT_BRICK_HEIGHT = 10;
    private static final int MORTAR_WIDTH = 1;

    private int chimneyWidth = DEFAULT_CHIMNEY_WIDTH;
    private int chimneyHeight = DEFAULT_CHIMNEY_HEIGHT;
    private int brickWidth = DEFAULT_BRICK_WIDTH;
    private int brickHeight = DEFAULT_BRICK_HEIGHT;

    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.GRAY);
        }
        g.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2));

        // Save the current graphics transformation
        AffineTransform oldTransform = g.getTransform();

        // Translate and rotate the graphics context to draw the chimney at the desired position and angle
        g.translate(startPoint.x, startPoint.y);
        g.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle));

        // Draw masonry chimney
        drawBrickwork(g);

        // Restore the old graphics transformation
        g.setTransform(oldTransform);
    }

    private void drawBrickwork(Graphics2D g) {
        // Draw bricks and mortar joints
        int numBricksX = chimneyWidth / (brickWidth + MORTAR_WIDTH);
        int numBricksY = chimneyHeight / (brickHeight + MORTAR_WIDTH);

        int startX = -chimneyWidth / 2;
        int startY = -chimneyHeight;
        for (int i = 0; i < numBricksY; i++) {
            for (int j = 0; j < numBricksX; j++) {
                int brickX = startX + j * (brickWidth + MORTAR_WIDTH);
                int brickY = startY + i * (brickHeight + MORTAR_WIDTH);
                g.fillRect(brickX, brickY, brickWidth, brickHeight);
            }
        }
    }

    @Override
    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        return new Rectangle(startPoint.x - chimneyWidth / 2, startPoint.y - chimneyHeight, chimneyWidth, chimneyHeight);
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {
        chimneyWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_CHIMNEY_WIDTH);
        chimneyHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_CHIMNEY_HEIGHT);
        brickWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_BRICK_WIDTH);
        brickHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_BRICK_HEIGHT);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

This version draws a masonry-style chimney with bricks and mortar joints. You can further enhance this design by adding more details or variations in the brickwork pattern.

Here's the Stairs class with the variables and methods renamed:

java
import java.awt.*;
import java.awt.geom.AffineTransform;

public class Stairs implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_STAIRS_WIDTH = 20;
    private static final int DEFAULT_STAIRS_HEIGHT = 40;
    private static final int DEFAULT_STEP_WIDTH = 5;
    private static final int DEFAULT_STEP_HEIGHT = 10;
    private static final int MORTAR_WIDTH = 1;

    private int stairsWidth = DEFAULT_STAIRS_WIDTH;
    private int stairsHeight = DEFAULT_STAIRS_HEIGHT;
    private int stepWidth = DEFAULT_STEP_WIDTH;
    private int stepHeight = DEFAULT_STEP_HEIGHT;

    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.GRAY);
        }
        g.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2));

        // Save the current graphics transformation
        AffineTransform oldTransform = g.getTransform();

        // Translate and rotate the graphics context to draw the stairs at the desired position and angle
        g.translate(startPoint.x, startPoint.y);
        g.rotate(Math.toRadians(rotationAngle));

        // Draw masonry stairs
        drawSteps(g);

        // Restore the old graphics transformation
        g.setTransform(oldTransform);
    }

    private void drawSteps(Graphics2D g) {
        // Draw steps and mortar joints
        int numStepsX = stairsWidth / (stepWidth + MORTAR_WIDTH);
        int numStepsY = stairsHeight / (stepHeight + MORTAR_WIDTH);

        int startX = -stairsWidth / 2;
        int startY = -stairsHeight;
        for (int i = 0; i < numStepsY; i++) {
            for (int j = 0; j < numStepsX * 2 + 1; j++) {
                int stepX = startX + j * (stepWidth + MORTAR_WIDTH);
                int stepY = startY + i * (stepHeight + MORTAR_WIDTH);
                g.fillRect(stepX, stepY, stepWidth, stepHeight);
            }
        }
    }

    @Override
    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        return new Rectangle(startPoint.x - stairsWidth / 2, startPoint.y - stairsHeight, stairsWidth, stairsHeight);
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {
        stairsWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_STAIRS_WIDTH);
        stairsHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_STAIRS_HEIGHT);
        stepWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_STEP_WIDTH);
        stepHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_STEP_HEIGHT);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

This class now represents a Stairs object with properties and methods corresponding to stairs instead of a chimney.

Sure, here's a basic implementation of a StorageBox class:

java
import java.awt.*;

public class StorageBox implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_BOX_WIDTH = 60;
    private static final int DEFAULT_BOX_HEIGHT = 40;
    private static final int DEFAULT_BOX_DEPTH = 30;

    private int boxWidth = DEFAULT_BOX_WIDTH;
    private int boxHeight = DEFAULT_BOX_HEIGHT;
    private int boxDepth = DEFAULT_BOX_DEPTH;

    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.GRAY);
        }
        g.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2));

        g.drawRect(startPoint.x, startPoint.y, boxWidth, boxHeight);
        g.drawLine(startPoint.x, startPoint.y, startPoint.x - boxDepth, startPoint.y - boxDepth);
        g.drawLine(startPoint.x + boxWidth, startPoint.y, startPoint.x + boxWidth - boxDepth, startPoint.y - boxDepth);
        g.drawLine(startPoint.x, startPoint.y + boxHeight, startPoint.x - boxDepth, startPoint.y + boxHeight - boxDepth);
        g.drawLine(startPoint.x + boxWidth, startPoint.y + boxHeight, startPoint.x + boxWidth - boxDepth, startPoint.y + boxHeight - boxDepth);

        g.drawLine(startPoint.x - boxDepth, startPoint.y - boxDepth, startPoint.x - boxDepth, startPoint.y + boxHeight - boxDepth);
        g.drawLine(startPoint.x + boxWidth - boxDepth, startPoint.y - boxDepth, startPoint.x + boxWidth - boxDepth, startPoint.y + boxHeight - boxDepth);
    }

    @Override
    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        return new Rectangle(startPoint.x - boxDepth, startPoint.y - boxDepth, boxWidth + boxDepth, boxHeight + boxDepth);
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {
        boxWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_BOX_WIDTH);
        boxHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_BOX_HEIGHT);
        boxDepth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_BOX_DEPTH);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

This class represents a storage box with a rectangular shape and lines indicating its depth. Adjustments can be made to its appearance and functionality as needed.

import java.awt.*;

public class Storage implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_STORAGE_WIDTH = 80;
    private static final int DEFAULT_STORAGE_HEIGHT = 60;
    private static final int DEFAULT_STORAGE_DEPTH = 40;

    private int storageWidth = DEFAULT_STORAGE_WIDTH;
    private int storageHeight = DEFAULT_STORAGE_HEIGHT;
    private int storageDepth = DEFAULT_STORAGE_DEPTH;

    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.GRAY);
        }
        g.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2));

        // Draw outer storage box
        g.drawRect(startPoint.x, startPoint.y, storageWidth, storageHeight);

        // Draw inner lines to indicate depth
        g.drawLine(startPoint.x, startPoint.y, startPoint.x - storageDepth, startPoint.y - storageDepth);
        g.drawLine(startPoint.x + storageWidth, startPoint.y, startPoint.x + storageWidth - storageDepth, startPoint.y - storageDepth);
        g.drawLine(startPoint.x, startPoint.y + storageHeight, startPoint.x - storageDepth, startPoint.y + storageHeight - storageDepth);
        g.drawLine(startPoint.x + storageWidth, startPoint.y + storageHeight, startPoint.x + storageWidth - storageDepth, startPoint.y + storageHeight - storageDepth);

        g.drawLine(startPoint.x - storageDepth, startPoint.y - storageDepth, startPoint.x - storageDepth, startPoint.y + storageHeight - storageDepth);
        g.drawLine(startPoint.x + storageWidth - storageDepth, startPoint.y - storageDepth, startPoint.x + storageWidth - storageDepth, startPoint.y + storageHeight - storageDepth);
    }

    @Override
    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        return new Rectangle(startPoint.x - storageDepth, startPoint.y - storageDepth, storageWidth + storageDepth, storageHeight + storageDepth);
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {
        storageWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_STORAGE_WIDTH);
        storageHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_STORAGE_HEIGHT);
        storageDepth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_STORAGE_DEPTH);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

Sure, here's a more detailed implementation of a storage container with added features such as handles, hinges, and a lid:

java
import java.awt.*;

public class StorageContainer implements DesignElement {
    private static final int DEFAULT_CONTAINER_WIDTH = 80;
    private static final int DEFAULT_CONTAINER_HEIGHT = 60;
    private static final int DEFAULT_CONTAINER_DEPTH = 40;
    private static final int DEFAULT_HANDLE_SIZE = 10;

    private int containerWidth = DEFAULT_CONTAINER_WIDTH;
    private int containerHeight = DEFAULT_CONTAINER_HEIGHT;
    private int containerDepth = DEFAULT_CONTAINER_DEPTH;
    private int handleSize = DEFAULT_HANDLE_SIZE;

    private Point startPoint;
    private boolean isSelected = false;
    private int rotationAngle = 0;

    public Point getStartPoint() {
        return startPoint;
    }

    public void setStartPoint(Point startPoint) {
        this.startPoint = startPoint;
    }

    @Override
    public void draw(Graphics2D g) {
        if (isSelected) {
            g.setColor(Color.MAGENTA);
        } else {
            g.setColor(Color.GRAY);
        }
        g.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2));

        // Draw outer container box
        g.drawRect(startPoint.x, startPoint.y, containerWidth, containerHeight);

        // Draw lid
        g.drawLine(startPoint.x, startPoint.y, startPoint.x - containerDepth, startPoint.y - containerDepth);
        g.drawLine(startPoint.x + containerWidth, startPoint.y, startPoint.x + containerWidth - containerDepth, startPoint.y - containerDepth);
        g.drawLine(startPoint.x, startPoint.y + containerHeight, startPoint.x - containerDepth, startPoint.y + containerHeight - containerDepth);
        g.drawLine(startPoint.x + containerWidth, startPoint.y + containerHeight, startPoint.x + containerWidth - containerDepth, startPoint.y + containerHeight - containerDepth);

        g.drawLine(startPoint.x - containerDepth, startPoint.y - containerDepth, startPoint.x - containerDepth, startPoint.y + containerHeight - containerDepth);
        g.drawLine(startPoint.x + containerWidth - containerDepth, startPoint.y - containerDepth, startPoint.x + containerWidth - containerDepth, startPoint.y + containerHeight - containerDepth);

        // Draw handles
        int handleX = startPoint.x + containerWidth / 2 - handleSize / 2;
        int handleY = startPoint.y - handleSize / 2;
        g.fillRect(handleX, handleY, handleSize, handleSize);
        g.fillRect(handleX, handleY + containerHeight, handleSize, handleSize);

        // Draw hinges
        int hingeX = startPoint.x - containerDepth / 2;
        int hingeY = startPoint.y - containerDepth / 2;
        g.fillRect(hingeX, hingeY, handleSize, handleSize);
        g.fillRect(hingeX + containerWidth - containerDepth, hingeY, handleSize, handleSize);
    }

    @Override
    public Rectangle getBounds() {
        return new Rectangle(startPoint.x - containerDepth, startPoint.y - containerDepth, containerWidth + containerDepth, containerHeight + containerDepth);
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isSelected() {
        return isSelected;
    }

    @Override
    public void setSelected(boolean selected) {
        isSelected = selected;
    }

    @Override
    public void resize(double scale) {
        containerWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_CONTAINER_WIDTH);
        containerHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_CONTAINER_HEIGHT);
        containerDepth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_CONTAINER_DEPTH);
        handleSize = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_HANDLE_SIZE);
    }

    @Override
    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }
}

This StorageContainer class represents a storage container with a rectangular shape, lid, handles, and hinges. You can adjust the dimensions and appearance of the storage container as needed.

        g.fillRect(hingeX + containerWidth - containerDepth, hingeY, handleSize, handleSize);

        return isSelected;
    }

        isSelected = selected;
    }

        containerWidth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_CONTAINER_WIDTH);
        containerHeight = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_CONTAINER_HEIGHT);
        containerDepth = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_CONTAINER_DEPTH);
        handleSize = (int) (scale * DEFAULT_HANDLE_SIZE);

    public void rotate(int angle) {
        rotationAngle = angle;
    }

Architecture Overview of the code
ChatGPT

The code provided consists of several Java classes that form a simple floor plan designer application. Here's an overview of the architecture and the purpose of each class:

  1. App (Main Class):

    • This is the main class that contains the main method.
    • It extends JFrame to create the main window of the application.
    • It sets up the UI layout, including the drawing panel, toolbox, and function box.
    • It also sets up the menu bar for file operations, editing, and help.

  2. DrawingPanel:

    • This class represents the panel where users can draw floor plan elements.
    • It extends JPanel and implements various mouse listeners to handle drawing actions.
    • It contains methods to draw, save, load, and clear the canvas.

  3. DesignElement (Interface):

    • This interface defines the common behavior for all design elements that can be drawn on the drawing panel.
    • It includes methods for drawing the element, getting its bounds, checking if it's selected, resizing, and rotating.

  4. BarElement:

    • This class represents the toolbox on the side of the application window.
    • It extends JPanel and contains buttons for selecting different drawing tools (elements).

  5. BarFunction:

    • This class represents the function box at the top of the application window.
    • It extends JPanel and contains buttons for various functions like saving, loading, clearing, etc.

  6. Individual Element Classes (e.g., Sofa, Chair, Desk, etc.):

    • These classes represent different types of design elements that users can draw on the canvas.
    • Each class implements the DesignElement interface and provides its implementation for drawing, resizing, rotating, etc.

  7. Other Supporting Classes:

    • There may be other supporting utility classes or data structures used within the application, such as custom shapes, styles, or file handlers.

Overall, the architecture follows a typical Model-View-Controller (MVC) pattern, where the DesignElement interface acts as the model defining the common behavior, the UI components (e.g., DrawingPanel, BarElement, BarFunction) act as the view, and the main class (App) coordinates the interaction between the model and the view. The individual element classes represent the different types of entities within the application domain.
